docs.lead_paragraph: Congress wrapped up a bruising session by passing a $127 billion measure that angered both fiscal conservatives and liberal environmentalists.

headline.seo: Congress Approves Transportation and Student Loan Package
headline.main: Congress Approves a $127 Billion Transportation and Student Loan Package
headline.print_headline: Congress Approves a $127 Billion Transportation and Student Loan Package

docs.abstract: Congress wraps up a bruising session by giving final approval to legislation that combines a two-year transportation measure with bills to extend subsidized student loans and revamp federal flood insurance.
docs.snippet: Congress wrapped up a bruising session by passing a $127 billion measure that angered both fiscal conservatives and liberal environmentalists.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney has proposed tax breaks for individuals buying coverage, increased competition among insurers and greater flexibility for states to make health care more affordable.

headline.seo: Parsing a Romney Alternative to Obama’s Health Care Law
headline.main: On Health Care Policy, Romney Favors G.O.P. Consensus
headline.print_headline: Parsing Romney’s Choices on Health Care

docs.abstract: Mitt Romney faces increased pressure to flesh out alternatives to the health care reform law, which the Supreme Court has upheld and which he and Republicans have professed to despise.
docs.snippet: Mitt Romney has proposed tax breaks for individuals buying coverage, increased competition among insurers and greater flexibility for states to make health care more affordable.

docs.lead_paragraph: Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr., who took abuse for supposedly botching the oral argument in the case, pressed the argument that the individual mandate could be considered a tax.

headline.seo: In Health Ruling, Vindication for Donald Verrilli
headline.main: Vindication for Maligned Lawyer in Justices’ Decision
headline.print_headline: Piled With Scorn, Lawyer Ends Up on Top

docs.abstract: Supreme Court decision upholding the health care reform law is a vindication for Solicitor General Donald B Verrilli, whose performance during oral arguments in March was much maligned.
docs.snippet: Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr., who took abuse for supposedly botching the oral argument in the case, pressed the argument that the individual mandate could be considered a tax.

docs.lead_paragraph: Opponents of the health care law were buoyed by the Supreme Court’s limiting of Congress’s power under the commerce clause of the Constitution.

headline.seo: Health Care Won, but Congress May Have Lost
headline.main: In Obama’s Victory, a Loss for Congress
headline.print_headline: In Obama’s Victory, A Loss For Congress

docs.abstract: James B Stewart Common Sense column argues that the Supreme Court decision upholding the Affordable Care Act may prove a Pyrrhic victory for supporters of expansive Congressional power; notes that Chief Justice John G Roberts Jr, in his majority opinion, rejected the widely held expansive view of the commerce clause of the Constitution, a key tool in the government's ability to regulate economic activity.
docs.snippet: Opponents of the health care law were buoyed by the Supreme Court’s limiting of Congress’s power under the commerce clause of the Constitution.

docs.lead_paragraph: Right now, it's scary to get sick, because if you don't die from the sickness, you die when you see the bill. GLADYS VASQUEZ, 50, a Houston home health aide who lacks health insurance. [A11]

docs.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Sundance) THE QUIET AMERICAN (2002) Michael Caine portrays Thomas Fowler, a British journalist who flees a loveless marriage in England to live in Southeast Asia and report on the Vietnamese fight for independence from French colonial rule. He becomes infatuated with Phuong (Do Thi Hai Yen, above with Mr. Caine), a beautiful former taxi dancer, in a relationship that can last only as long as he keeps his job. Then Alden Pyle (Brendan Fraser), an American intelligence officer, comes along. And he wants Phuong too. ''Fowler may be the richest character of Mr. Caine's screen career,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times of this adaptation of Graham Greene's novel, by Phillip Noyce. ''This great English actor gives a performance of astonishing understatement whose tone wavers delicately between irony and sadness.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Fred de Sam Lazaro reports from Niger, where the government and relief organizations are trying to fend off mass starvation while increasing tree vegetation, so that the country will be less imperiled by drought.
